abstract.text: Text the user can select or edit to send an action message to a target when the user presses the Return key.

inlineContent.text: class to implement its user interface. Text fields display text either as a static label or as an editable input field. The content of a text field is either plain text or a rich-text attributed string. Text fields also support line wrapping to display multiline text, and a variety of truncation styles if the content doesn’t fit the available space.
, provides the methods for setting the values of the text field, such as
. There are corresponding methods to retrieve values.
In macOS 12 and later, if you explicitly call the
property on your text field, the framework will revert to a compatibility mode that uses
. The text view also switches to this compatibility mode when it encounters text content that’s not yet supported.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary for an accessibility element to act as navigable static text.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary for an accessibility element to act as static text.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A view that displays a list of values in a pop-up menu where the user selects a value or types in a custom value.
A specialized view, such as a button or text field, that notifies your app of relevant events using the target-action design pattern.
The value of the receiver’s cell as a double-precision floating-point number.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an
object.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
An object that coordinates the layout and display of text characters.
A text field optimized for performing text-based searches.
A text field that hides the typed text.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
The most general programmatic interface for objects that manage text.
A protocol that describes specific kinds of input content types.
A set of optional methods implemented by the delegate of an
object to edit text and change text formats.
Text the user can select or edit to send an action message to a target when the user presses the Return key.
The style of bezel the text field displays.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the text field is editable and accepts first responder status.
A Boolean value that controls whether the Touch Bar displays the character picker item for rich text fields.
A Boolean value that controls whether single-line text fields tighten intercharacter spacing before truncating the text.
A Boolean value that controls whether the user can change font attributes of the text field’s string.
The color of the background the text field’s cell draws behind the text.
The text field’s bezel style, square or rounded.
The text field’s delegate.
A Boolean value that controls whether the text field’s cell draws a background color behind the text.
A Boolean value that controls whether the user can drag image files into the text field.
Creates a text field for use as a static label that displays styled text, doesn’t wrap, and doesn’t have selectable text.
Initializes a text field for use as a static label that uses the system default font, doesn’t wrap, and doesn’t have selectable text.
Initializes a single-line editable text field for user input using the system default font and standard visual appearance.
Initializes a text field for use as a multiline static label with selectable text that uses the system default font.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the text field automatically completes text as the user types.
A Boolean value that controls whether the text field draws a bezeled background around its contents.
A Boolean value that controls whether the text field draws a solid black border around its contents.
A Boolean value that controls whether the user can edit the value in the text field.
A Boolean value that determines whether the user can select the content of the text field.
The strategy that the system uses to break lines when laying out multiple lines of text.
The maximum number of lines a wrapping text field displays before clipping or truncating the text.
The attributed string the text field displays when empty to help the user understand the text field’s purpose.
The string the text field displays when empty to help the user understand the text field’s purpose.
The maximum width of the text field’s intrinsic content size.
Ends editing in the text field and, if it’s selectable, selects the entire text content.
Sets the text field’s string value using the embedded character as the keyboard mnemonic.
The delegate that provides text suggestions for the receiving text field and responds to the user highlighting and selecting items.
The color of the text field’s content.
Posts a notification to the default notification center that the text is about to go into edit mode.
Posts a notification when the text changes, and forwards the message to the text field’s cell if it responds.
Posts a notification when the text is no longer in edit mode.
Requests permission to begin editing a text object.
Performs validation on the text field’s new value.
An object that enhances the text display capabilities of a cell.
A protocol that a text field delegate can use to control its field editor action menu.
A view that draws text and handles user interactions with that text.
A set of optional methods that text view delegates can use to manage selection, set text attributes, work with the spell checker, and more.
A text field that converts text into visually distinct tokens.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A protocol that a custom class can adopt to manage the enabled state of a UI element.
Integrate Writing Tools support, including support for inline replacement
animations, to your custom text views on macOS.

doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/App.title: Adding Writing Tools support to a custom AppKit view

abstract.text: Incorporate the system text cursor into your custom text UI in AppKit.

doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/App.title: Adopting the system text cursor in custom text views

abstract.text: Modify the behavior of Writing Tools in standard macOS text views,
and adjust your app’s behavior while the feature is active.

doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/App.title: Customizing Writing Tools behavior for AppKit views

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
